caseTitle: REX v EMANUEL ADEBOW ALE AND FIVE OTHERS
summary: The appellants were convicted in the Supreme Court for stealing and receiving stolen gin from a Customs Warehouse. The first three were convicted of both stealing under section 390(4)(c) and receiving under section 427 of the Criminal Code, while the last three were convicted only of receiving. On appeal, the West Africa Court of Appeal held that the trial judge did not misdirect the jury by failing to warn them about accomplice testimony, as the co-accused's statements did not materially prejudice each other and the rule on corroboration applies only to prosecution witnesses. The court found sufficient evidence of guilty knowledge based on suspicious circumstances, including sale below market price, unusual packaging, and indirect payment. It affirmed that assisting in disposal of stolen goods constitutes receiving under section 427. The court also ruled that the wife of an accused could not be called without her husband's application under section 8(2). The redundant convictions for both stealing and receiving were quashed due to the alternative nature of the charges, with sentences reduced accordingly. The appeals against conviction were dismissed, but sentences for the last three appellants were reduced to eighteen months' hard labour.
verdict: Convictions for receiving upheld; convictions for stealing quashed due to redundant verdicts; sentences reduced for last three appellants
winningSide: Crown (partial; convictions upheld on receiving, but some sentences reduced and stealing convictions quashed)
citations: R. v. Barnes and Richards, 27 C.A.R. 154
R. v. Mallam Mahamado, W.A.C.A. (unreported), 23rd March, 1940
rationaleHighlights: No need for corroboration warning as co-accused statements did not materially prejudice others
Guilty knowledge inferred from suspicious circumstances: price, packaging, payment method, and quantity
Assisting in disposal of stolen goods constitutes receiving under section 427
Wife of accused could not be called without husband's application under section 8(2)
Double conviction on alternative counts constitutes error; only one conviction should stand
Subsidiary role of last three appellants justified reduced sentence
